text: finally help is on its way to the
besieged town of Medea where more than
20 people are reported to have starved
to death this UN and Red Cross convoy
carrying the first food supplies to the
town since last October and if it can
deliver its load it'll be enough to feed
the people there for a month Medea which
lies in the hills near the border with
Lebanon is home to 40,000 people and
this morning a crowd gathered at one of
the checkpoints waiting for the
desperately needed food supplies to
arrive this apparently is the impact the
siege has had the most vulnerable left
emaciated the unconfirmed videos were
provided by activists inside the town
seven-year-old Mohammad Issa said he had
not eaten for a week when this was
filmed on the streets of Medea family
scramble for whatever they can get to
stay alive apparently surviving on small
packs of salt while in this unverified
video someone picks leaves to make a
meager meal we don't have any indication
of how many people may have starved to
death we know that in this city there's
around 40,000 people who urgently need
food assistance we're taking in supplies
that should feed them for a month but
what we really need is access all the
time to ensure this kind of situation
doesn't happen again so there is now a
glimmer of hope for the people of Medea
who've been blockaded by government
forces for so long but today's deal also
includes sending food supplies to two
villages besieged by the rebels both
sides in this conflict using starvation
as a weapon of war Richard galpin BBC
News
